key_points: Former White House chief of staff Mark Meadows suggested Donald Trump could become the Speaker of the House if Republicans win control.
The U.S. Constitution allows for a non-member of the House to be elected as Speaker.
No non-member has ever been elected Speaker, but some non-members have received votes for the position.
Rep. Brendan Boyle introduced a resolution to amend the rules to require the Speaker to be a member of the House, but no action has been taken on it.
Meadows endorsed the idea on a podcast hosted by Trump ally Steve Bannon.
Meadows criticized the current House Republican leadership, specifically mentioning Kevin McCarthy.
Meadows' comments highlight tensions within the Republican Party ahead of the midterm elections.
Criticism of McCarthy includes his handling of bipartisan infrastructure bill votes and his reaction to Rep. Paul Gosar's controversial video.
Former Ohio Governor John Kasich described Meadows' comments as "crazy" on CNN.
The discussion around Trump potentially becoming House Speaker reflects ongoing divisions and strategies within the Republican Party.
spokespersons: Mark Meadows (Former White House Chief of Staff)
